data.enText: spoiled
spoiled
spoilt
spoilt

data.chText: 破坏；搞坏；糟蹋；毁掉
data.enText: to change sth good into sth bad, unpleasant, useless, etc.

data.chText: 天气不好，破坏了我们的露营旅行。
data.enText: Our camping trip was spoilt by bad weather.

data.chText: 别让他搞得你一晚上不开心。
data.enText: Don't let him spoil your evening.

data.chText: 那些高楼大厦破坏了这一带的景致。
data.enText: The tall buildings have spoiled the view.

data.chText: 别吃太多坚果，会影响你的食欲。
data.enText: Don't eat too many nuts─you'll spoil your appetite (= will no longer be hungry at the proper time to eat) .

data.chText: 废选票
data.enText: spoiled ballot papers (= not valid because not correctly marked)

data.chText: 溺爱；娇惯；宠坏
data.enText: to give a child everything that they ask for and not enough discipline in a way that has a bad effect on their character and behaviour

data.chText: 她那几个孩子给她宠坏了。
data.enText: She spoils those kids of hers.

data.chText: 善待；格外关照
data.enText: to make sb/yourself happy by doing sth special

data.chText: 为什么不到顶级饭店度个周末，让自己享受享受呢？
data.enText: Why not spoil yourself with a weekend in a top hotel?

data.chText: 我过生日那天他真让我受宠若惊。
data.enText: He really spoiled me on my birthday.

data.chText: 变坏；变质；腐败
data.enText: to become bad so that it can no longer be eaten
be spoiling for a fight

data.chText: 按捺不住想打架
data.enText: to want to fight with sb very much
spoil the ship for a ha'p'orth/ha'pennyworth of tar

data.chText: 因小失大
data.enText: to spoil sth good because you did not spend enough money or time on a small but essential part of it
too many cooks spoil the broth

data.chText: 厨师多了烧坏汤；人多手杂反坏事；人多添乱
data.enText: if too many people are involved in doing sth, it will not be done well

data.chText: 赃物；战利品；掠夺物

data.enText: or
goods taken from a place by thieves or by an army that has won a battle or war

data.chText: 成功所带来的好处；权力地位的连带利益
data.enText: the profits or advantages that sb gets from being successful

data.chText: 身居高位的连带利益
data.enText: the spoils of high office

data.chText: （开掘等时挖出的）弃土，废石方
data.enText: waste material that is brought up when a hole is dug, etc.

means: (开掘等时挖出的)弃土，废石方

ex.chText: 这个病毁掉了他的事业。
ex.enText: The illness has ruined his career.

ex.chText: 恶劣的天气毁掉了他们的野餐。
ex.enText: The bad weather ruined their picnic.

ex.chText: 这场雨毁了她新剪的头发。
ex.enText: The rain ruined her newly cut hair.

synonyms.bx: 强调程度，指完全毁掉，用于具体的事物时，指该事物虽然被毁坏，但依然存在。

ex.chText: 该国由于内战满目疮痍，人们生活非常艰难。
ex.enText: People lived a hard life as the country had been ravaged by civil war.

ex.chText: 由于酗酒，他的身体渐渐垮了。
ex.enText: His health was gradually ravaged by excessive drinking.

synonyms.bx: 强调程度严重，通常用被动语态。

ex.chText: 整个景区环境都被垃圾破坏了。
ex.enText: The whole scenic spot is spoiled by litter.

ex.chText: 别让这件事毁了我们的聚会。
ex.enText: Don't let the incident spoil our party.

synonyms.bx: 指使某物的优良特性或特征不复存在，但此物依然存在，语气没有ruin 强。

data.enText: be spoiling for a fight

data.chText: 按捺不住想打架
data.enText: to want to fight with sb very much
spoil the ship for a ha'p'orth/ha'pennyworth of tar

data.chText: 因小失大
data.enText: to spoil sth good because you did not spend enough money or time on a small but essential part of it
too many cooks spoil the broth

data.chText: 厨师多了烧坏汤；人多手杂反坏事；人多添乱
data.enText: if too many people are involved in doing sth, it will not be done well

tr: the act of stripping and taking by force
the act of spoiling something by causing damage to it
example: her spoiling my dress was deliberate

tr: (usually plural) valuables taken by violence (especially in war)
example: to the victor belong the spoils of the enemy

tr: become unfit for consumption or use
example: the meat must be eaten before it spoils

tr: destroy and strip of its possession
example: The soldiers raped the beautiful country

tr: have a strong desire or urge to do something
example: She is itching to start the project
He is spoiling for a fight

tr: make a mess of, destroy or ruin
example: I botched the dinner and we had to eat out
the pianist screwed up the difficult passage in the second movement

tr: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
example: What ultimately frustrated every challenger was Ruth's amazing September surge

value.boxr_value: American English uses the form spoiled as the past tense and past participle. British English uses either spoiled or spoilt. 美国英语中过去式和过去分词为 spoiled，英国英语中可用 spoiled 或 spoilt。

value.def: If you spoil something, you prevent it from being successful or satisfactory.

example.ex: It's important not to let mistakes spoil your life...
example.tran: 重要的是不要让错误毁了你的生活。

example.ex: Peaceful summer evenings can be spoilt by mosquitoes.
example.tran: 宁静的夏夜可能会被蚊子破坏掉。

value.def: If you spoil children, you give them everything they want or ask for. This is considered to have a bad effect on a child's character.

example.ex: Grandparents are often tempted to spoil their grandchildren whenever they come to visit.
example.tran: 祖父母每次来访都往往禁不住要娇惯孙辈。

example.ex: A spoilt child is rarely popular with other children...
example.tran: 被宠坏的孩子很难得到其他孩子的喜爱。

example.ex: Oh, that child. He's  so spoiled.
example.tran: 哦，那个孩子。他被宠坏了。

value.def: If you spoil yourself or spoil another person, you give yourself or them something nice as a treat or do something special for them.

example.ex: Spoil yourself with a new perfume this summer...
example.tran: 今年夏天买瓶新香水慰劳一下自己吧。

example.ex: Perhaps I could employ someone to iron his shirts, but I wanted to spoil him. He was my man.
example.tran: 也许我可以雇别人来熨他的衬衫，但我想好好宠他。他是我爱的男人。

value.def: If food spoils or if it is spoilt, it is no longer fit to be eaten.

example.ex: We all know that fats spoil by becoming rancid...
example.tran: 我们都知道油脂变质后会发臭。

example.ex: Some organisms are responsible for spoiling food and cause food poisoning...
example.tran: 有些生物会导致食物变质并引起食物中毒。

example.ex: Some of my apples were spoilt last year by grubs inside the fruit.
example.tran: 去年我的一些苹果被果内的虫子给蛀坏了。

example.ex: ...the potential health problems from spoiled food.
example.tran: 变质食物可能引起的健康问题

value.def: If someone spoils their vote, they write something illegal on their voting paper, usually as a protest about the election, and their vote is not accepted.

example.ex: They had broadcast calls for voters to spoil their ballot papers...
example.tran: 他们通过广播呼吁选民们投无效选票。

example.ex: The results showed that 7.2% of the voters cast blank or spoiled ballots.
example.tran: 结果显示，7.2 %的选民投了空白或无效票。

value.tran: (因在其上写违法的内容而)使(选票)无效

value.def: The spoils of something are things that people get as a result of winning a battle or of doing something successfully.

example.ex: True to military tradition, the victors are now treating themselves to the spoils of war...
example.tran: 按照军事惯例，胜者正在分享战利品。

example.ex: Competing warlords and foreign powers scrambled for political spoils.
example.tran: 相互争斗的军阀及外国列强们正在争夺政治上的收益。

value.tran: 战利品;因成功获得的好处

value.def: If you say that someone is spoilt for choice or spoiled for choice, you mean that they have a great many things of the same type to choose from.

example.ex: At lunchtime, MPs are spoilt for choice in 26 restaurants and bars.
example.tran: 到了午餐时间，议员们有 26 家之多的餐厅和酒吧可供选择。
